# Tools for Reporting & Storytelling

## Quarto

-   is a (relatively) new, open-source, scientific, and technical publishing system
-   aims to make the process of creating and collaborating dramatically better

::: {.smaller}

*Subsequent slides are adapted from the [excellent Quarto Dashboard workshop](https://posit-conf-2024.github.io/quarto-dashboards/) by Mine √áetinkaya-Rundel* from posit::conf(2024)

:::

## Quarto ‚ûù many outputs {background-image="images/quarto-to-docs.png"}

With Quarto you can weave together narrative text and code to produce elegantly formatted output as documents, web pages, blog posts, books, and more...

## Installing Quarto

Best Approach:

 - Go to the [Quarto website and download!](https://quarto.org/docs/get-started/)

## Quarto version

::: callout-tip
Run the following in your Terminal to find your Quarto version:

``` {.bash filename="Terminal"}
quarto --version
```
:::

# Quarto Documents

## Documents

 - Lots of options `.pdf`, `.html`, `.docx`
 - Easiest to start with `.html`!
 - We can embed our code and figures with the text!
 - Click "`Render`" = AutoMagically make a report!

## Let's Make One!

**Download and Open [`csci-summary.qmd`](https://github.com/ryanpeek/cabw2025/blob/main/csci-summary.qmd) in RStudio and‚Ä¶**

1. `Render` the document.
2. Replace the name with your own and re-`render`.
3. Inspect the parts of the document and change something else or add some new text. Re-`Render`!
4. Compare with your neighbor and find what they did!

## Making a `.Qmd` Document from Scratch

:::: columns
::: {.column width="40%"}
1. In RStudio, File > New File > Quarto Document
2. Add a Title, and keep everything else as a default, then click `Create`!
3. We can always change things later
:::
::: {.column width="10%"}
:::
::: {.column width="50%"}

![](../images/new_quarto.png)
:::
::::

## Quarto Components: *3 main pieces*

## Part 1: The Metadata (`yaml`) header

```
---
title: "CSCI Summary"
format: html

execute: 
  echo: true
---
```

 - This needs to go at the top of our document
 - It provides info about what format our document will take
 - Many themes and many [MANY options](https://quarto.org/docs/output-formats/html-basics.html)

## Part 2: The Markdown Text

Markdown is designed to be easy to write and easy to read, and can be saved/published as plain text.


> [See Quarto website for more!](https://quarto.org/docs/authoring/markdown-basics.html)

## Part 3: The Code Chunks

Can use multiple languages, just need to:

 - sandwich code between "fences" of at least three backticks1. An optional language provides syntax highlight



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(ggplot2)
```
:::

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
